case_name: Masood Alam v. Union of India ors. and Abdul Bari Kairanvi v. Union of India

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 469 of 1972 filed by Masood Alam under Article 32 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 469 and 470 of 1972. Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 470 of 1972 filed by Abdul Bari Kairanvi under Article 32 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 469 and 470 of 1972. Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Court made short order on December 20, 1972 directing release of Masood Alam unless required in other case.

anchor.surface_text: In writ petition number 469 of 1972 we made a short order on December 20, 1972 directing the release of Masood Alam unless he was required in some other case,

facts.text: Masood Alam arrested on June 15, 1972 pursuant to detention order dated June 14, 1972 by District Magistrate, Aligarh under section 3(1)(a)(i) and (ii) of MISA 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Masood Alam, detenu-petitioner, was arrested on June 15, 1972 pursuant to an order of detention dated June 14, 1972. No copy of that order is produced on the record.

facts.text: Grounds of detention served on Masood Alam on June 17, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention signed by the District Magistrate, Aligarh were served on the, petitioner on June 17, 1972, pursuant to s. 8 of the Act.

facts.text: No approval of Masood Alam's first detention by State Government under section 3(3) of MISA.

anchor.surface_text: The Government, it appears, did not accord its approval of the petitioners detention as required by s. 3 (3) of the Act.

facts.text: Release order served on Masood Alam on June 26, 1972 at about 12 noon, dated June 25, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: According to para 22 of the Writ Petition, the contents of which are not controverted, as expressly stated in para 12 of the counter affidavit, on June 26, 1972 at about 12

facts.text: Fresh detention order for Masood Alam passed on June 25, 1972 by Governor of U.P. under section 3(1) of MISA, served June 26, 1972 at 3.30 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: A fresh order of detention was also passed on June 25, 1972. This order was made by the Governor of U.P. under s. 3 (1) of the Act and was served on the petitioner on June 26, 1972 at about 3.30 p.m.

facts.text: Court quashed Masood Alam's detention order dated June 25, 1972 due to lack of fresh facts after revocation/expiry of earlier order.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this submission does possess merit and deserves to be accepted. Section 14 speaks of revocation or expiry of a detention order.

facts.text: Abdul Bari Kairanvi arrested on June 3, 1972 for organizing procession defying section 144 CrPC, under section 188 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Bari Kairanvi, petitioner in this writ petition, an associate of Masood Alam ... was arrested on June 3, 1972 when he had organised in the City of Aligarh a procession in defiance of the order issued under S. 144, Cr. P.C.

facts.text: Abdul Bari Kairanvi's detention order made on June 14, 1972 by District Magistrate under section 3(1)(a)(i) and (ii) of MISA.

anchor.surface_text: On June 14, 1972 an order was made by the District Magistrate for the petitioners detention under s. 3 (1) (a) (i) and (ii) of the Act as amended by the Defence of India Act 42 of 1971.

facts.text: Abdul Bari Kairanvi's detention approved by State Government on June 25, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: His detention was duly reported to the State Government on June 18, 1972 and the State Government gave its approval on June 25, 1972

facts.text: Abdul Bari Kairanvi's case sent to Advisory Board on July 13, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: His case was sent to the Advisory Board on July 13, 1972 and the Board conveyed its decision on August 18/21, 1972.

facts.text: Abdul Bari Kairanvi's detention confirmed on August 30, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: His detention was confirmed on August 30, 1972.

facts.text: Communal riots occurred in Aligarh on June 5, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The general ,atmosphere of communal tension prevailing in that city ultimately culminated in the unfortunate communal riots on June 5, 1972.

facts.text: Masood Alam is organiser of Youth Majlis at Aligarh, a paramilitary organisation training Muslims in use of lathi, swords, knives.

anchor.surface_text: Those grounds read That you have been exciting communal feelings amongst Muslims... that you are organiser at Aligarh of Youth Majlis a paramilitary Organisation which imparts training to. Muslims in the use of lathi, swords and knives, etc.

facts.text: Masood Alam visited Pakistan and returned on April 29, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: You visited Pakistan and returned from there on 29-4-1971 and participated in a meeting addressed by Shri Afaq Ahmad, Organiser Youth Majljs, U.P.

facts.text: Abdul Bari Kairanvi visited Pakistan in November 1971, returned November 30, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: You visited Pakistan in November, 1971 for arranging the transfer of funds collected by Shri Masood Alam in Pakistan to Aligarh... That you visited Pakistan in November, 1971 and returned from there on 30-11-1971

facts.text: War between India and Pakistan began on December 3, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Judicial notice under s. 57 of the Indian Evidence Act can be taken of the fact that the war between India and Pakistan actually began on December 3, 1971 lasting for about a fortnight.

facts.text: Court upheld Abdul Bari Kairanvi's detention as grounds relevant to security of State and public order.

anchor.surface_text: The facts contained in the grounds reproduced earlier seem to us to be clearly relevant for the purpose of forming an opinion that they endanger both maintenance of public order and security of the State.

facts.text: Masood Alam arrested on June 15, 1972 also under sections 107/117/151 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: according to the return of the State of Uttar Pradesh as averred in para27 r of the counter-affidavit of Shri R. K. Kaul, Special Secre- tary, the petitioner was arrested on 15th June 1972 under section 107/117/151, Cr. P.C.

facts.text: Abdul Bari Kairanvi made representation on July 15/24, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner had made his representation on July 15/24, 1972 through the District Magistrate who forwarded it to the Government on July 29, 1972.

facts.text: Youth Majlis training camp at Varanasi attended by Masood Alam.

anchor.surface_text: You went to participate in Youth Majlis training camp at Varanasi. You were trained in the use of knife and demonstrated the same at a function of the Youth Majlis

facts.text: Masood Alam attended meeting at residence on October 29, 1971 discussing Youth Majlis training.

anchor.surface_text: You attended the meeting held at your residence on 29-10-71 wherein training programme of Youth Majlis in use of knife and aiming by air gun was discussed.

facts.text: Abdul Bari Kairanvi collected Rs. 700 for Youth Majlis from Varanasi, Pratapgarh etc.

anchor.surface_text: You collected Rs. 700 for Youth Majlis from Varanasi, Pratapgarh and other places.

issues.text: Whether the first detention order dated June 14, 1972 was invalid or mala fide so as to vitiate the second detention order dated June 25, 1972?

anchor.surface_text: He has tried to assail that order with the object of showing mala fides of the detaining authority in making ,the second order. In this connection it is noteworthy that according to the return of the State of Uttar Pradesh as averred in para27 r  of the counter-affidavit of Shri R. K. Kaul, Special Secre- tary, the petitioner was arrested on 15th June 1972 under section 107/117/151, Cr. P.C.

issues.text: Whether the grounds of detention under the first order only suggest a threat covered by CrPC Chapter VIII proceedings like s.107, rendering detention an abuse of MISA?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bashir Ahmad the counsel for the detenu has contended that the grounds of detention dated June 17, 1972 served on the petitioner under s. 8 of the Act only suggest a threat to the security of the State and the maintenance of public, order and that this does not mean that the petitioner was likely to act in the near future in a manner prejudicial to the security of State and maintenance of public order.

issues.text: Whether there was imminent likelihood of the petitioner acting prejudicially justifying the second detention order under MISA s.3?

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the second order also it has been suggested that there is no imminent likelihood of the Petitioner acting in a prejudicial manner and that his detention is thus an abuse or misuse of the power of detention conferred by the Act.

issues.text: Whether service of the second detention order dated June 25, 1972 on the petitioner while in jail custody renders the detention void?

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner had been served with the order of detention dated June 25, 1972 when he was in jail and that such service is invalid rendering the petitioners detention void.

issues.text: Whether the grounds of detention are rendered invalid because they relate to events more than a year prior to the detention order?

anchor.surface_text: It has also been pointed out that the grounds relate to a period more than a year prior to the order of detention. This according to the submission also renders the order mala fide.

issues.text: Whether the second detention order dated June 25, 1972 is invalid under s.14 MISA as made without fresh facts after revocation or expiry of the first detention order?

anchor.surface_text: The next point raised on behalf of the petitioner is that the earlier order of detention was either revoked or had expired with the result that unless the present detention pursuant to the order dated June 25, 1972 is passed on fresh facts arising after the expiry or revocation of the earlier order it must be held to be invalid.

issues.text: Whether the grounds of detention for Abdul Bari Kairanvi are irrelevant to security of State or public order under MISA s.3?

anchor.surface_text: According to the petitioners counsel Mr. Bashir Ahmed, the grounds on which the petitioners detention has been ordered are irrelevant and, therefore, the detention is void. Emphasis is laid on the submission that the Youth Majlis and the Muslim Majlis are both organisations which do not advocate communal conflict or disharmony and the object of both of them is social service of the society.

issues.text: Whether some grounds of detention served on Abdul Bari Kairanvi are vague, vitiating the detention order?
Whether the petitioner's activities and associations posed a threat to security of India, security of State, and maintenance of public order justifying detention under MISA s.3?

anchor.surface_text: The facts contained in the grounds reproduced earlier seem to us to be clearly relevant for the purpose of forming an opinion that they endanger both maintenance of public order and security of the State.

issues.text: Whether the detention orders comply with constitutional safeguards for personal liberty under Art.32 and related provisions?

arguments.court_reasoning: Grounds relevant to public order and state security; accepts facts as correct, reviews relevance only; judicial notice of war timing

arguments.court_reasoning: Not vague when read in context; precise details provided

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this submission does possess merit and deserves to be accepted. Section 14 speaks of revocation or expiry of a detention order.

anchor.surface_text: Articles 25 to 28 and Art. 30 in Part III accord to the Right to Freedom of Religion and the Right of Minorities to Establish and Administer Educational Institutions, the status of fundamental rights

arguments.claim: No permission to refer to unfiled constitution of Youth Majlis as irrelevant to scope of enquiry

anchor.surface_text: In support of this contention the counsel sought to refer to the printed constitution of the Organisation in Urdu which was not permitted, not being on the record and not being relevant to the limited scope of enquiry in the present proceedings.

arguments.claim: Detention complies with procedural safeguards like approval, Advisory Board, representation consideration

anchor.surface_text: His detention was duly reported to the State Government on June 18, 1972 and the State Government gave its approval on June 25, 1972

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that it was in November, 1971 that the petitioner is said to have gone to Pakistan  it is asserted in the grounds that he visited Pakistan in November

holdings.text: The earlier order of detention cannot be described as either illegal or mala fide merely because the grounds also attract provisions of Chapter VIII CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The submission that the use of the word likely in this para only brings the petitioners case within the purview of the provisions of Chapter VIII  Security Proceedings  of the Criminal Procedure Code thereby justifying only proceedings under s. 107 of the Code and that an order of detention in such circumstances is an abuse and misuse of the provisions of the Act has only to be stated to be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grounds relevant and germane to MISA objectives; overlap with CrPC does not invalidate; cites precedents Sahib Singh Duggal, etc.

holdings.text: The challenge to the first detention order does not establish mala fides vitiating the second detention order.

anchor.surface_text: Although the petitioners present detention is founded on the order dated June 25. 1972 the earlier order was challenged with the sole object of showing that the present detention is also mala fide because the authorities are determined to keep the petitioner in custody irrespective of the existence or non- existence of valid grounds. We are not impressed by this submission and are unable to hold that the circumstances in which the earlier order was made in any way suggest mala fides on the part of the detaining authority in making the second order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of mala fides from sequence or challenge to prior order.

holdings.text: Court does not objectively review the imminence of likelihood of prejudicial acts if detaining authority satisfied on germane grounds.

anchor.surface_text: If the detaining authority is of opinion on grounds which are germane and relevant, that it is necessary to detain a person from acting prejudicially as contemplated by s. 3 of the Act then it is not for this Court to consider objectively how imminent is the likelihood ,of the detenu indulging in these activities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preventive detention based on subjective satisfaction; constitutional freedoms balanced against public interest.

holdings.text: There is no legal bar to serving a detention order on a person in jail custody if likely to be released soon and free to act prejudicially.

anchor.surface_text: There is no legal bar in serving an order of detention on a person who is in jail custody if he is likely to be released soon thereafter and there is relevant material on which the detaining authority is satisfied that if free, the person concerned is likely to indulge in activities prejudicial to the security of the State or maintenance of public order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Makhan Singh; cites Rameshwar Shaw; dual custody not futile if prior custody ending soon.

holdings.text: Past conduct or antecedent history, though over a year old, can justify detention if proximate and rationally connected to need for detention.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt the past conduct, activities or antecedent history should ordinarily be proximate, in point of time and should have a rational connection with the conclusion that the detention of the person is necessary but it is for the detaining authority who has to arrive at a subjective satisfaction in considering the past activities and coming to his conclusion if on the the basis of those activities he is satisfied that the activities of the person concerned are such that he is likely to indulge in prejudicial activities necessitating his detention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detaining authority assesses proximity subjectively; cites Ujjagar Singh.

holdings.text: Second detention order dated June 25, 1972 is invalid under section 14 MISA as no fresh facts arose after revocation or expiry of the first detention order.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this submission does possess merit and deserves to be accepted. Section 14 speaks of revocation or expiry of a detention order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.14 bars fresh detention on same facts to prevent evasion of maximum detention period; purposive interpretation protects liberty; cites Hadibandhu Das, Kshetra Gogoi.

holdings.text: Detention order for Abdul Bari Kairanvi quashed? No, upheld as grounds relevant to security of State and public order.

anchor.surface_text: The facts contained in the grounds reproduced earlier seem to us to be clearly relevant for the purpose of forming an opinion that they endanger both maintenance of public order and security of the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court examines relevance, not truth of grounds; activities incite communal violence, extra-territorial loyalties during war tension; judicial notice of war.

holdings.text: Grounds of detention served on Abdul Bari Kairanvi are not vague.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Read in context, grounds provide precise details; relevant and germane.

holdings.text: Jurisdiction of preventive detention depends on subjective satisfaction of detaining authority; court reviews only relevance/germaneness of grounds, not truth.

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction of preventive detention sometimes described as jurisdiction of suspicion depends on subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes from judicial trials; inherent in preventive detention law.

holdings.text: Activities inciting communal feelings and violence, even under religious guise, threaten public order and state security justifying detention.

anchor.surface_text: It is undeniable that hostility amongst the citizens founded on differences in religious faiths Is a deadly poison for healthy existence and progress of a secular, egalitarian society like ours. And when violence is advocated and injected in such hostility, it is idle to suggest that such activities cannot fall within the mischief designed to be prevented by the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutional equality of religions; no superior status; balancing freedoms.

holdings.text: Preventive detention must strictly comply with statutory limits to protect personal liberty under Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The rule of law reigns supreme in this Republic and no person on the soil of free India can be deprived of his personal liberty without the authority of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction of ss.13-14 MISA; cites Manu Bhushan.

precedents.citation: Sahib Singh Duggal v. Union of India 1

anchor.surface_text: provided the authority concerned is satisfied of the necessity of the detention as contemplated by the Act see Sahib Singh Duggal v. Union of India 1 , Mohammad Salem Khan v. C. C. Bose 2  and Borjahan Gorey v. The Stale of West Bengal 3 . The jurisdiction of preventive detention sometimes described as jurisdiction of suspicion depends on subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority.

precedents.case_name: Sahib Singh Duggal v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: preventive detention cannot be mala fide merely because objectionable activities also attract provisions of Ch. VIII Cr. P.C. if grounds relevant and authority satisfied of necessity

precedents.citation: Mohammad Salem Khan v. C. C. Bose 2

anchor.surface_text: see Sahib Singh Duggal v. Union of India 1 , Mohammad Salem Khan v. C. C. Bose 2  and Borjahan Gorey v. The Stale of West Bengal 3 . The jurisdiction of preventive detention sometimes described as jurisdiction of suspicion depends on subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority. It is designed to prevent the mischief from being committed by depriving its suspected author of the necessary facility for carrying out his nefarious purpose.

precedents.case_name: Mohammad Salem Khan v. C. C. Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: preventive detention cannot be mala fide merely because objectionable activities also attract provisions of Ch. VIII Cr. P.C. if grounds relevant and authority satisfied of necessity

precedents.citation: Borjahan Gorey v. The Stale of West Bengal 3

anchor.surface_text: Union of India 1 , Mohammad Salem Khan v. C. C. Bose 2  and Borjahan Gorey v. The Stale of West Bengal 3 . The jurisdiction of preventive detention sometimes described as jurisdiction of suspicion depends on subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority. It is designed to prevent the mischief from being committed by depriving its suspected author of the necessary facility for carrying out his nefarious purpose. This Jurisdiction is thus essentially different from that of judicial trials for the commission of offences and also from preventive security proceedings in criminal courts.

precedents.case_name: Borjahan Gorey v. The State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: preventive detention cannot be mala fide merely because objectionable activities also attract provisions of Ch. VIII Cr. P.C. if grounds relevant and authority satisfied of necessity

precedents.citation: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: is numberlegal bar in serving an order of detention on a person who is in jail custody if he is likely to be released soon thereafter and there is relevant material on which the detaining authority is satisfied that if free, the person concerned is likely to indulge in activities prejudicial to the security of the State or maintenance of public order. The decision in Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab 1  does number lay down the broad proposition canvassed.

precedents.case_name: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: order of detention under Defence of India Rules r.30(1)(b) only where person would be free to carry out prejudicial activity otherwise

precedents.citation: Rameshwar Shaw v. District Magistrate, Burdwan 1

anchor.surface_text: On plain construction of that sub-rule it was held that an order permitted by it could be served on a person who would be free otherwise to carry out his prejudicial activities and such a freedom could number be predicated ,of Makhan Singh Tarsikka, petitioner in that case. It is numbereworthy that the Court after referring with approval to its earlier decision in Rameshwar Shaw v. District Magistrate, Burdwan 1  observed Besides when a person is in jail custody and criminal proceedings are pending against him,

precedents.case_name: Rameshwar Shaw v. District Magistrate Burdwan
precedents.cited_proposition: detention order can be served after acquittal even if prepared earlier when in custody

precedents.citation: Ujjagar Singh v. State of Punjab 2

anchor.surface_text: No doubt the past conduct, activities or antecedent history should ordinarily be proximate, in point of time and should have a rational connection with the conclusion that the detention of the person is necessary but it is for the detaining authority who has to arrive at a subjective satisfaction in considering the past activities and coming to his conclusion if on the the basis of those activities he is satisfied that the activities of the person concerned are such that he is likely to indulge in prejudicial activities necessitating his detention. As observed in Ujjagar Singh v. State of Punjab 2  it is largely from prior events or past conduct and antecedent history of a person showing tendencies or inclinations of a person concerned that an inference can be drawn whether he is likely even in the future to act in a manner prejudicial to the public order.

precedents.case_name: Ujjagar Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: inference of future prejudicial activity from past conduct and antecedent history

precedents.citation: Hadibandgu Das v. The DistrictMagistrate, Cuttack 1

anchor.surface_text: In support of this submission reliance has been placed on S. 14 of the Act which reads 14  1  Without prejudice to the provisions of section 21 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 a detention order may, at any time, be revoked or modified-  a  notwithstanding that the order has been made by an officer mentioned in sub-section  2  of section 3 by the State, Government to which that officer is subordinate or by the Central Government.  b  notwithstanding that the order has been made by a State Government, by the Central Government. The revocation or expiry of a detention order shall number bar the making of a fresh detention order under section 3 against the same person in any case where fresh facts have arisen after the date of revocation or expiry on which the Central Government or a State Government or an officer, as the case may be, is satisfied that such an order should be made. Support has also been sought from Hadibandgu Das v. The DistrictMagistrate, Cuttack 1  which, was a case under the Preventive Detention Act  IV of 1950 .

precedents.case_name: Hadibandhu Das v. District Magistrate Cuttack
precedents.cited_proposition: fresh detention order requires fresh facts after revocation or expiry of earlier order under Preventive Detention Act s.13(2)

precedents.citation: Kshetra Gogoi v. State of Assam 2

anchor.surface_text: DistrictMagistrate, Cuttack 1  which, was a case under the Preventive Detention Act  IV of 1950 . The language of S. 13 2  of that Act is identical with that of S. 14 2  reproduced above. This decision was followed in Kshetra Gogoi v. State of Assam 2  also a case under Act 4 of 1950. In our opinion, this submission does possess merit and deserves to be accepted.

precedents.case_name: Kshetra Gogoi v. State of Assam
precedents.cited_proposition: fresh detention order requires fresh facts after revocation or expiry of earlier order under Preventive Detention Act s.13(2)

precedents.citation: Manu Bhushan Roy Prodhan v. State of West Bengal  1

anchor.surface_text: The submission on behalf of the State that the petitioners activities are so highly communal and prone to encourage violent communal activities that it was considered absolutely necessary to detain him in the interest of security of the State and maintenance of public order cannot prevail in face of the statutory restrictions and the guaranteed constitutional right which is available to all persons. The rule of law reigns supreme in this Republic and numberperson on the soil of free India can be deprived of his personal liberty without the authority of law. As observed by this Court in Manu Bhushan Roy Prodhan v. State of West Bengal  1  The Act encroaches on the highly cherished right of personal liberty by conferring on the executive extraordinary power to detain persons without trial by coming to subjective decisions.

precedents.case_name: Manu Bhushan Roy Prodhan v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: detaining authority must act strictly within limitations of Act to protect personal liberty

precedents.citation: Sampat Prakash v. State of Jammu Kashmir  2

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent reference was also made to Sampat Prakash v. State of Jammu Kashmir  2  dealing with detention under J. K. Preventive Detention Act  J. K. Act 13 of 1964 . Though in that Act there is a similar provision s. 14 2  of that Act in the judgment there is numberreference to that section and it appears that numberquestion similar to the one- raised before us was urged and adjudicated upon there.

precedents.case_name: Sampat Prakash v. State of Jammu and Kashmir
precedents.cited_proposition: detention under J&K Preventive Detention Act

precedents.citation: S. Azeez Basha v. Union of India  .

anchor.surface_text: This agitation was carried an in connection with a bill relating to the Aligarh Muslim University ignoring that the legal position in respect of this University had been authoritatively settled by this Court as far back as October, 1967 in S. Azeez Basha v. Union of India  . These activities clearly bring the petitioners case within s. 3 of the Act, being calculated to incite communal violence.

precedents.case_name: S. Azeez Basha v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: legal position regarding minority character of Aligarh Muslim University settled

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction of preventive detention sometimes described as jurisdiction of suspicion depends on subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority.

In writ petition number 469 of 1972 we made a short order on December 20, 1972 directing the release of Masood Alam unless he was required in some other case, reserving our reasons for his release to be given later. We now proceed to deal with the arguments advanced on his behalf and give our reasons for our decision.
